Award.AwardTitle: Nonclassical MHC-dependent Innate T Cell Ontogeny and Function in the Amphibian Xenopus
Award.AbstractNarration:
T cells are well known for their role in generating the capacity of the adaptive immune system to identify and respond to diverse non-self antigens. The selectivity of a T cell arises from the T cell receptor variant it displays at its surface, with an individual?s T cell population containing a massive repertoire of distinct T cell receptor variants. However, a subgroup of T cells displays a limited or invariant set of T cell receptors. These so called innate T cells (iT cells) are thought to be rapid responders to infections, recognizing via their T cell receptors conserved molecular determinants in pathogens and providing defense in advance (or absence) of an adaptive immune response. However little is known about how iT cells differentiate or the role they play in immune responses. With preliminary data demonstrating that iT cells are well represented in tadpoles of the frog Xenopus, this project addresses the general hypothesis that the external development of tadpoles requires a capacity to mount rapid immune responses to viruses and bacteria, that the responses be mediated by a small population of immune competent cells, and that these requirements are met by iT cells. This research will extend our understanding of the evolution, biology and importance of iT cells in host/pathogen interactions. It also has the potential to suggest immunologically informed strategies for controlling pathogens and their role in amphibian decline. Undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate students will be extensively involved in all aspects of the research, which includes opportunities to study fundamental immunology, development, microbiology and evolution, as well as to learn a range of modern molecular, cellular and reverse genetic techniques. The PI will recruit one or two undergraduate students during the academic year, and in collaboration with the NSF BIO REU program and the Summer Undergraduate Research Program, at least one additional minority undergraduate each summer. The PI also directs the Xenopus laevis Research Resource for Immunobiology, which provides reagents, animals, information, assistance, training and outreach to scientists and the public.

Two specific hypotheses guide this project: (i) ectothermic vertebrates with rapid external development critically rely on iT cells for an innate-like T cell repertoire; and (ii) that class Ib restricted iT cells are pivotal in orchestrating immune responses against viral and bacterial pathogens. This hypothesis will be addressed in vivo in X. laevis tadpoles and adults with innovative reverse genetic loss-of-function approaches that combine transgenesis with RNAi or CRISPr/Cas genome editing technologies to determine the roles of class Ib molecules in the development and function of iT cells in X. laevis. The research will also use and further develop class Ib tetramers and antibodies to identify distinct iT cell subsets. The specific aims are: (1) To identify and characterize class Ib genes regulating the development and function of distinct iT cell lineages using qPCR, immunohistology and in situ hybridization as well as class Ib-deficient transgenic lines; (2) To characterize distinct class Ib-restricted iT cell lineages in tadpoles and adults using a combination of class Ib tetramers and monoclonal antibodies with flow cytometry, cell sorting and fluorescence microscopy; (3) To elucidate the roles of distinct class Ib-restricted iT cell lineages of tadpoles and adults in vivo during immune response against ecologically relevant pathogens including the ranavirus Frog virus 3, Mycobacterium marinum, and Aeromonas hydrophila. The successful application of tools (class Ib tetramers and antibodies) and innovative loss-of-function by transgenesis technologies will further empower the Xenopus research model.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Conventional T cells are key player of the adaptive immune system that identify and respond to antigens derived from pathogens that are present on the surface of cell bound to polymorphic classical major histocompatibility (MHC) molecules. The selectivity of a T cell arises from the T cell receptor variant it displays at its surface, with an individual’s T cell population containing a massive repertoire of distinct T cell receptor variants.  However, there is a less well characterized subgroup of T cells that display limited or invariant sets of T cell receptors. These so-called innate-like (i)T cells (iT cells) are rapid responders to infections, recognizing via their invariant T cell receptors highly conserved pathogenic ligands presented by non-polymorphic MHC molecules and providing early defense and regulating an adaptive immune response. Until recently, these iT cells were considered to be a minor specialized T cell type confined to mammalian species. 

Our work has challenged this misconception, since we have shown that iT cells are present in the amphibian Xenopus, and thus are represented outside mammals. To date, Xenopusis the only species outside mammals where an immune surveillance system based on non-polymorphic MHC class I-like directing the development and function of iT cells has been characterized. Notably, this system is more prevalent in naturally classical MHC class I-deficient tadpoles than in MHC class I competent adult frogs; and includes a iT cell (iVa6) subset reminiscent of mammalian iNKT cells critical for anti-viral response and an MHC class I-like (XNC4) binding unusually long peptides that confers resistance to mycobacterial infections. We developed reverse genetic approaches combining transgenesis with either RNA silencing or CRISPR/Cas9-mediated gene disruption as well as MHC tetramer technology applied to Xenopus. With the iT cell subset restricted by the class I-like XNC10 (iVa6 T cells) are critical in tadpoles to control infection by the ranavirus Frog virus 3 (FV3), which is a major pathogen implicated in amphibian decline. functional iVa6 T cells are also important for a timely and effective adult viral clearance. We have further identified and characterized another non-polymorphic MHC class I-like molecule, XNC4, which is required for the development of distinct iT cell subset (iVα45) defined by a defined invariant TCRrearrangement. The deficiency of iVα45 T cells dramatically impairs tadpole resistance to infection by Mycobacterium marinum, a natural pathogen for many vertebrate species including humans and an accepted model for M. tuberculosis. We have also generated a XNC4 tetramer that recognizes a distinct iT cell population, which is recruited in the peritoneum and liver in conjunction with infected macrophages and M. marinum dissemination.  Unexpectedly, the analysis of TCR of XNC4-tetramer positive cells indicate that XNC4 interacts with a few additional iT cell subsets besides iVα45 T cells. This multiplicity of interaction is consistent with the mass spectrometry analysis revealing that XNC4 binds an abundant area of uncharacteristically long peptides (9-11mer) with a single putative anchor. In addition to provide the first direct evidence of ligands associated with an MHC molecule from a basal tetrapode vertebrate, these data provide novel insights into the evolution and structural adaptation of non-conventional presentation of ligand by MHC class-like molecules.

Overall, this research has unveiled the importance of non-polymorphic MHC class I-like and innate-like T cells in aquatic vertebrates, particularly during early development and in antimicrobial immunity. Notably, our findings have extended our understanding of the evolution, biology and importance of iT cells in host/pathogen interactions. Our study also has the potential to suggest immunologically informed strategies for controlling pathogens and their role in amphibian decline. Highschool, undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate students (including from underrepresented groups) have been extensively involved in all aspects of the research, which included opportunities to study fundamental immunology, development, microbiology and evolution, as well as to learn a range of modern molecular, cellular and reverse genetic techniques. The animals, reagent and tools as well as innovative loss-of-function by transgenesis technologies have further empowered the Xenopus research model and have been widely disseminated and made available through a website, publications and presentations at multiple conferences.
